1. THE PROPOSAL

II. INTRODUCTION

The Government of Indonesia accords high priority to the development of eastern
2.
Indonesia. In the context of the Government's development objectives for the eastern region
with respect to poverty reduction, employment generation, environment conservation and
balanced regional development, the Government of Indonesia requested Bank assistance for
the Sustainable Agriculture Development Project in Irian Jaya in January 1990. In response to
the request, the Bank approved in October 1990 a technical assistance (TA) 1' for the
preparation of the Project. The feasibility study was completed in August 1992. A Bank Fact-
Finding Mission was fielded in December 1992 to review the proposed Project, and held
discussions with the Government and various concerned implementing agencies to resolve
Project-related issues. This was followed by an Appraisal Mission from 1 to 20 March 1993.
The Appraisal Mission reached an agreement with the Government on technical, organizational,
implementation, financial and economic aspects of the Project, and confirmed that the
Government accorded high priority to the Project. Loan negotiations with authorized
representatives of the Government were held in Manila from 22 to 24 September 1993.

Ill. BACKGROUND

A.	

The Ag riculture Sector

1.	

General

The development strategy of Indonesia as outlined in the Fifth Five-Year
3.
Development Plan FYI 989/90-1993/94 (Repelita V), and as expected to carry over to Repelita
VI (1994/95-1 998/99)-a' aims at sustainable economic growth, employment generation, equitable
distribution of income, alleviation of poverty, and conservation of natural resources and the
environment. The agriculture sector is expected to contribute substantially to achieving these
objectives.

4.
In spite of its rapid industrialization and urbanization over the past decade,
Indonesia is basically an agrarian country. The agriculture sector accounts for almost 20 per
cent of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) and more than half of national employment.
Two thirds of the country's rural households and 10 per cent of the urban households depend
on agriculture for their livelihood. The predominant agriculture subsector is food crops, which
constitute over 60 per cent of the agricultural GDP. The sector has made a major contribution
to economic development, employment generation and poverty reduction in Indonesia.
Agriculture value-added grew by an average of about 4 per cent per annum during the last ten

5.
Of the 42 million hectares (ha) of agricultural land in Indonesia, about half is
under permanent cultivation, and the rest is under shifting cultivation (25 per cent) and livestock
pasture (25 per cent). The area being intensively cultivated consists of about 7.7 million ha of
wetland food crops (including 5.3 million ha of irrigated land), 7.6 million ha of tree crops and
5.3 million ha of upland food crops. Except for large plantations comprising about 20 per cent
of the tree crop area, Indonesia's agricultural production is dominated by its 18 million
smallhàlders, most of whom farm less than 1 ha.

6.
Over the past two decades, improved productivity and income levels in the
agriculture sector have significantly reduced the incidence of rural poverty. According to the
National Socioeconomic Survey of 1990, the population living below poverty line in rural areas
declined rapidly, from 44 million in 1976 to 18 million in 1990. In relative terms, the decline is
much sharper, from 40.4 per cent to 14.3 per cent. Furthermore, there was a faster decline in
the rural areas than in urban areas where the population below the, poverty line declined from
38.8 per cent to 16.8 per cent during the same period.

7.
Although the growth figures are impressive and the incidence of poverty in rural
areas has been drastically reduced, most of this has occurred in the irrigated lowlands, which
are mainly planted to rice and represent only a quarter of the land area under permanent
cultivation. Other areas, except for some rainted land planted with tree crops, have largely been
bypassed by the eatlier development efforts and continue to be characterized by high levels of
poverty. Here, three quarters of households with agriculture as their main source of livelihood,
live below the poverty line of about $100 per capita per  annum.V In the eastern region,
especially in lnan Jaya Province, the incidence of poverty remains high. In addition, the
increasing population in settled villages is exerting pressure on existing farms and the
surrounding marginal and sloping lands, and has resulted in resource degradation. Sizeable
areas are at environmental risk as poor farmers are forced to subsist on a declining resource
base.

2.	

Agriculture Develo pment in lrian Java

8.
Irian Jaya, one of Indonesia's least developed provinces, has a total area of
414,800 square kilometers and is the country's largest province. About .84 per cent of the total
area is under forest and 12 per cent under bush and scrub vegetation. Only 4 per cent is being
utilized for agriculture, tree crop plantations and transmigrant settlements. The population is
about 1.65 million, a great majority of whom (some 80 per cent) live in small rural traditional
communities and depend upon traditional farming and hunting/forest food gathering systems.
Indigenous farmers generally practice shifting cultivation within the traditional boundaries of their
landholdings. The landholding occupied by each family within the group is recognized by
traditional land law and the tribal chief. The typical cropping pattern includes sweet potatoes,
taro, cassava and maize with practically no fertilizer or other agrochemicals. Yields are low and
have been declining in recent years due to soil erosion and fertility depletion. The agriculture
actMties are generally subsistence oriented, with farmers growing as much  as the family
requires to eat. Poverty in Irian Jaya is a widespread rural phenomenon with over 70 per cent

9.
The farmers are organized into indigenous communities each consisting of 40 to
50 families, generally with annual per capita incomes below the national poverty line. Most, if
not all the communities lack basic physical and social amenities and services, as well as
essential agricultural inputs such as improved seeds/planting material, fertilizers, pesticides,
credit and other farm inputs. Poor primary and secondary farm roads has been a major
constraint to the intensification and diversification of agnculture and the expansion of agro-
industries. The Inanese have virtually been bypassed by the country's mainstream development
initiatives in the agriculture and rural sectors.

B.	

Government Policies and Plans

1.	

General

10.
In the implementation of its successive five-year development plans (Repelitas)
since 1969 the Government's overall economic policy has been guided by the triple goals of
growth, equity and stability. As the main rural economic activity, agriculture has been expected
to be the major contributor to the achievement of these objectives. The major components of
the Government's strategy in this regard have been to achieve a rapid expansion in food crop
production to meet increasing domestic demand, to provide gainful employment for a rapidly
expanding population and to achieve more equitable regional development. The goals have
been effected through large investments in physical infrastructure for irrigation, drainage and
flood control; input subsidies; and farm support programs to encourage the adoption of new
production technologies. Parallel support was also provided in the tree crop subsector through
opening new areas to settle landless farmers under the Nucleus Estate and Smaliholder (NES)
scheme and through rehabilitation of unproductive smallholder tree crop areas under the Project
Management Unit scheme As a result, the growth of the agriculture sector has been
remarkable: agricultural output increased by an average of 4 per cent per annum during the
1 970s and 1 980s, and self-sufficiency in rice was achieved in 1984.

11.
In view of the development challenges posed by rural poverty and the
unsustainable farming conditions found in most nonimgated rural areas, the Government, during
Repelita IV (1984/85-1988/89), began to move away from its early agricultural development focus
on immediate production increases to a long-term strategy to promote more sustainable growth,
which emphasizes increasing productivity and conserving the underlying natural resource base.
Through this shift in strategy, the Government has made a concerted effort to increase the
production of nonrice food crops and smallholder tree crops. In doing so, particular attention
is being given to eastern Indonesia, which has the highest incidence of rural poverty.

12.
The Government recognizes that unsound agricultural practices undercut its
poverty reduction efforts and is therefore placing increased emphasis on land-use patterns,
watershed management, sustainable farming systems, vegetative soil conservation techniques
and location-specific research on agricultural practices that would maintain or enhance the
natural resource base. Coming to grips with these concerns over a widely dispersed
archipelago has also necessitated a move toward decentralized decision-making and greater
involvement of the rural community groups.

The Project Management Unit scheme involves the provision of credit and farm inputs
to assist small farmers to rehabilitate/expand their existing farm areas assisted by staff
from specially created Project Management Units.

 4

13.
The Government's development initiatives in the agricultural sector in Inan Jaya
place emphasis on the sustainable management of natural resources. The Government's
development program also places high priority on 'people centered development,' with a
community development and participatory approach sensitive to the local culture. To work
towards this objective, the provincial authorities have launched several sectoral and regional
development initiatives focused on village communities. These 'integrated' development
programs, which aim to accelerate village development, are currently being implemented in
various subdistricts (Kecamatans) in all of the eastern provinces. The programs cover
improvements in agnculture, transportation, health and education. Under these programs,
emphasis is given to increasing the strength and capacity of extension workers at the
Kecamatan level to carry out a diverse range of small-scale activities that respond directly to the
needs of the indigenous farmers.

C.	

External Assistance to the A griculture Sector

14.
An overview of external assistance to the agriculture sector of Indonesia during
the last decade is given in Appendix 1. The Bank, Japan and the World Bank are the major
funding agencies for the sector in terms of amount of assistance, while sources such as the
United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAQ),
Australia, Canada and the United States (US) have also been actively involved in the
development of this sector. The World Bank's assistance has focused on irrigation and tree
crop development through the NES concept. The World Bank has also assisted transmigration
projects, which generally include tree or food crop production as the main component. Japan's
assistance to the sector has concentrated on irrigation and flood control. Australia and Canada
have been assisting rural development or integrated agricultural development in priority regions
particulaily in eastern Indonesia. Recent US assistance has emphasized mainly policy reforms
in the agriculture sector particularly in natural resources management, the rural banking system
and agribusiness. Given the extent of external involvement in the agricultural sector, substantial
coordination at the policy, program and project level is required and has been achieved through
regular consultations between the funding agencies.

15.
External initiatives in Irian Jaya have been limited. The major initiatives include
nation-wide development schemes that include Irian Jaya, such as the World Bank's Agricultural
Training Ill, National Agricultural Extension Project Ill and Transmigration V; and the smaller
FAO/IFAD (International Fund for Agricultural Development) and UNDP projects, the Income
Generating Project for Small Farmers (better known as PK4 in Indonesia), which seeks to
improve the skills of farmers and enhance off-farm income opportunities. The Bank has
financed a NES project component in Irian  Jaya,!' where a 4,500 ha NES oil palm plantation
was successfully established. The Bank has also provided two project preparatory TAs for
feasibility studies and two loans for fisheries projects in Irian  Jaya.a' The other large-scale
project that targets solely Irian Jaya is the Irian Jaya Joint Development Foundation (IJJDF)
funded by the Government and the United Nations. The IJJDF, established in the 1 960$, has
been helping the poor peasants of Irian Jaya through direct and indirect small investments.
UNDP has been assisting IJJDF for more than two decades in strengthening its capability as
the major provincial lending institution. It has so far invested in sectors such as agriculture,

25. The people of the Project areas live in villages of 40 to 50 families. Population

2.	

Employment, Incomes and Poverty

26. Almost all rural households in the Project areas are generally subsistence farmers.
They practice shifting cultivation principally of sweet potatoes and other starch crops (taro,
cassava and yams). Rice and maize are now grown increasingly though not as staples.
Vegetables are commonly grown particularly in the highlands. Fruit trees, coffee, cashew, and
cocoa have been introduced during the last ten years by the Government and some NGOs. In
the lowland areas, cocoa is grown quite extensively. These crops are grown by farmers mainly
for the local market to enhance cash income. Traditional livestock husbandry shows marked
variations between Project areas and includes pigs (which are also maintained for ritual and
status purposes), poultry and cattle. Protein intake varies accordingly, and peoples' diet
generally remains carbohydrate based.

 8

Poverty is widespread in the Project area with annual household incomes ranging
27.
from about $260 to $490. The average household comprises 5-6 people. In the highland areas,
there is greater diversity of household income particularly with the emergence of semi-urban
markets offering good returns on fruits and vegetables. Cash surpluses are rare and this is
acutely felt particularly by the females. When school fees cannot be afforded, it is the females
who are first taken out of school. Cash is needed to purchase essential household items such
as soap, sugar, salt, cooking oil, kerosene and school uniforms and to pay medical expenses.
The social design survey for the Project encountered women who traveled up to 25 km a day
to sell fruit in the local market to obtain returns of less than $2.50 per trip that were required to
purchase basic household needs.

While the province as a whole is sparsely populated, pockets of high population
28.
densities exist within each indigenous ethnic group. These communities live in a permanent
area demarcated by the traditional land boundaries and practice swidden agriculture within their
traditional landholdings. The communities are usually organized under the leadership of a tribal
chief and live together in groups of families (keret). The cultivated farmland per family
comprises 2-4 sites of 0.1-0.4 ha each. Wrth a growing population in each localized area, the
farmers are under increasing pressure to increase productivity from existing lands or-encroach
into adjoining forest lands.

The farmers are aware that their agriculture practices are outmoded and that crop
29.
yields are declining. They are increasingly interested in extension advice and training to
improve their farming methods and cultivation practices, and to increase farm productivity. In
recent years, surplus sweet potatoes and small quantities of cash crops (such as vegetables,
peanuts, maize and cocoa/coffee) are being produced by some farmers and sold in local
markets to earn cash income. Part of the cash earned is used to purchase improved seed,
planting materials and even fertilizers to improve yields. Such progressive improvement in the
local agriculture system is especially prevalent in villages located near the town centers.
However, the absence of active agriculture rural development programs and the lack of
substantial cash income constrains most farmers from improving production through the use
of purchased inputs. Most farmers continue to have little or no access to credit and are faced
with other constraints, such as inadequate transport infrastructure. According to rapid social
appraisals done at selected Project sites during Project preparation stage, the indigenous
farmers are receptive to improved agricultural technologies and probably have the capacity and
potential to significantly improve farm productivity with appropriate assistance)-'

Health problems are extensive and sometimes severe. Malaria, bronchitis and
30.
diarrhea are the most common diseases. Related causes are diet, hygiene, access to clean
drinking water, and large families leaving mothers inadequate time for effective child rearing.
It is important for males in the local society to have many children. Yet every additional child
presents an additional burden to the family budget and to the mother in terms of her work
requirements, health and time available to look after the children. Thus, services such as health,
hygiene, family planning and related community education appear to be a major need.

4.	

Need. Opportunities and Constraints for Development

33.
Given the rudimentary state of development of village organizations in Irian Jaya
and the subsistence level of village economies, the need for development assistance is very
high. Community development is, at best, rudimentary and the development of local institutions
has been largely neglected. Rather than experiencing economic improvements, most
communities are enduring the reverse as pressures on land reduce the bush/fallow cycle and,
consequently the land's productivity. Incomes are probably declining at the same time that
subsistence is declining because of reduced productivity; thus there are greater requirements
for cash to supplement the reduced subsistence. Communities are therefore in an economic
squeeze of declining incomes and increasing cash needs. The Project provides an opportunity
for communities to manage their way out of the problem.

All communities encountered during the social design preparation for the Project
34.
have demonstrated their ability to change their economic practices, introduce new crops and
livestock, and change their traditional patterns of agriculture if assistance and access to
marketing is available. They have clearly demonstrated a demand for a broader range of crops.
A semi-government organization, LJJDF (para 15), has been operating in Irian Jaya for over
twenty years and has organized several smallholder plantations of coffee arabica, cocoa, rubber
and cashew trees and of vegetables. It organizes the provision of planting materials, farmer
training, the provision of small loans (in the form of minor equipment such as spades and
knives) to the farmers and marketing. A Catholic Mission in the highlands has similarly assisted
Irianese smallholders to undertake coffee plantations, and a commercial organization, PT Prima,
has recently established a 100 ha coffee plantation in collaboration with local Irianese.

The agricultural potential by Project area as assessed by the feasibility study and
35.
demonstrated by the farmers is as follows: (i) in Manokwan, farmers are cultivating potatoes,
taro and maize and have recently expanded into cocoa, fruit trees and upland rice; (ii) in
Sorong, staple crops are sweet potato and cassava, and farmers have begun planting
groundnut; (iii) in Fak Fak, farmers have traditionally grown sweet potato, and in recent years.
vegetables (brasicca, spinach and pepper chili), groundnut, fruits (jackfruit and papaya) and
cocoa have been cultivated; (iv) in Jayawijaya, farmers are trying to move from sweet potatoes
to vegetables, tobacco, maize, pulses and coffee; and (v) Merauke is particularly suited for
cashew plantations, which have been initiated.

Notwithstanding the above potential, the Project has to take account of other
36.
important constraints. The Inanese way of life is built around subsistence swidden agriculture,
though recently, this has been limited to areas within access of the village, thus allowing the
village to become a stable and permanent settlement. Being subsistence farmers, their energies
are directed at subsistence before they can consider cash or tree crop intensification. Thus, the
first priority of the Project should be to establish secure subsistence for each village, through
improved crop cultivation. The existing and old tree crop areas should be rehabilitated and
expand to economical size and should not conflict with the demands of subsistence farming.
The tree crop cultivation cycle should accordingly be timed to coincide with slack periods in the
subsistence farming calendar (which includes ritual activities related to tribal tradition).

Secure land titles are probably not essential for success of the Project. Local
37.
Irianese appear legally unsophisticated, have little notion of individual, alienable ownership rights
based on land certification principles, and prefer to adhere to the traditional rights (adat) system.
Land is owned in common by the community, though its temporary usage rights can be

 10

assigned to an individual by the community leadership and consensus. It will be important for
the Project and particularly for local government officials to take account of the traditional land
right system.

38. The issue of credit is complex. Some local Irianese smaliholders may not fully
understand the concept of credit, particularly the obligations and risks involved. Nevertheless,
NGOs and IJJDF have introduced credit to the smaliholders, particularly for vegetable and tree
crop development. These organizations also provide for the marketing of produce; thus they
have been able to manage the credit arrangement effectively by deducting debt-service
payments at source from the cash sale.

39. The situation of women also needs to be carefully considered. Traditionally, men
in the Irianese culture devoted substantial time to war and rituals, and relatively less to farming
and domestic duties. Women provided subsistence and nurtured the family. Men undertook
heavy manual tasks, such as land clearing, felling and making and maintaining fences. The
women managed cultivation and marketing. Thus, the woman's working day was and continues
to be longer than the mans and averages 200 days a year on the farm compared to the man's
average of 125 days a year. With changing circumstances, the older men particularly are finding
it difficult to adjust to a value system in which war and rituals have a decreasing role. They
need to be encouraged, however, to share the economic and work day burden with women
more equitably. The Project will have to ensure that the introduction of more intensified farming
does not exacerbate the workload problems already being coped with by the women.

40. Finally, the issue of markets is both an opportunity and a constraint. The Project
has been careful to choose sites that either have, or are planned to have in the near term, easy
access to urban or semi-urban market centers. NGOs, semi-government organizations and
private companies have been responsible for setting in motion local marketing arrangements
with varying degrees of efficiencies. However, the Project will have to take account of market
opportunities and arrangements before embarking on the promotion of specific crops in specific
Project areas.

B.	

Rationale

41. The traditional ethnic groups in Inan Jaya normally live in cluster of settlements
within the boundary of their traditional land and practice subsistence agriculture for their
livelihood. The Project area consists of pockets of indigenous farm lands where (I) the
population density is relatively high, (ii) the farming rotation cycle is too short to be sustainable,
(iii) the crop yields are low and have been declining, and (iv) in some areas the farming activities
are beginning to encroach into marginal and forest land, resulting in resource degradation.
Consequently, the indigenous agricultural production system is unable to provide for the
subsistence needs of the local population and is a threat to sustainable agricultural
development. The indigenous farmers are becoming more aware of their need to seek
improved farming methods and cultivation practices to increase farm productivity and to diversify
crop production.

42. Accordingly, there is a need for a project that addresses, in an integrated manner,
the needs of the indigenous farmers, and protects the environment through more effective
resource management. As indicated in paragraph 8, poverty in Irian Jaya is widespread and
agricultural activities are not sustainable in areas where population density is high. Marginal
land is being utilized in successive rotation to feed the increasing population. There is an urgent
need to improve existing farming methods to bring about sustainable agricultural production
practices that will lead to increased productivity, reduced poverty and conservation of the
environment.

C.	

Obiectives

43. The long-term goals of the Project are to reduce poverty, enhance the
socioeconomic status of the indigenous lrianese and stabilize the environment. The objectives
of the Project are (i) to increase agricultural productivity and household income; (ii) to introduce

and (iii) to put in place a self-sustaining community-based development process that enables

practices and increase production of a range of crops, adoption of agroecological measures
such as soil and water conservation using cover crops, improvement of rural infrastructure and
institutional strengthening of Government rural development agencies and local farmer groups.

A.	

Financial and Economic Analysis

1.	

Financial Analysis

The Project will directly benefit 28,000 farm households in 16 kecamatans
101.
(subdistricts) of Inan Jaya. These direct beneficiaries represent some 15 per cent of the total
population of the targeted kecamatans, where nine traditional ethnic groups are found. Most
Project participants are hard-core poverty peasants living in isolated hamlets, practicing shifting
cultivation supplemented by fishing, hunting and gathering of forest products. Currently, their
annual household income ranges from $260 to $490, which is below the poverty level of $500
per annum (assuming five people per household). With the implementation of the Project, the
annual household incomes will increase to $550 (for lowland food crop farmers), $580 (for
highland food crop farmers), $830 (for lowland cashew and food crop farmers), $920 (for
lowland cocoa and food crop farmers) and $1,400 (for highland coffee and food crops farmers).
The farm model analysis that compares the incremental income between the with and without
project situations is shown in Appendix 5. Additionally, significant income increases or
nutritional improvements can be expected with the expansion in fruit production and household
animals.

The 11,000 farmers participating in the tree crop production will receive wages
102.
for land clearing and conservation work and for maintenance work before the trees are mature
enough to bear fruit. The credit for tree crop establishment will be provided to participating
farmers at an annual interest rate based on the certificate rate of Bank Indonesia with a grace
period of five years. Cash flow analysis using the ceiling of 21 per cent is shown in Tables 8-10
of Appendix 5. Farmers will be able to repay their loan within 10 to 13 years after crop
establishment while retaining incremental cash flow during the period of credit repayment.

 22

103. At full development of the Project, farm productivity will increase significantly, with
the annuai incremental rise in output of the major crops estimated at 2,700 tons of cocoa, 2,400
tons of arabica coffee, 2,500 tons of cashew, 13,500 tons of sweet potatoes, 1,650 tons of maize
and 6,250 tons of vegetables and other annual crops. The farm-gate value of the produce is
estimated at $14 million. Exports of tree crop produce will generate annual foreign exchange
earnings of about $8 million.

2.	

Economic Analysis

104. In constant 1993 prices, the Project is estimated to yield  an economic internal rate
of return (EIRR) of 15 per cent over Its economic life of 25 years (see Appendix 5, Table 13).
EIRR has been computed with the full investment costs for rural infrastructure, environment
management, farming system research and other support services, but without the benefit from
those services, because they are not readily quantifiable.

105. Other major assumptions included in the economic analysis are (i) a physical
implementation period of six years; (ii) economic prices of cocoa and coffee based on the latest
World Bank price projections for agricultural commodities, expressed in constant 1993 dollars
and adjusted for transport, handling, and other marketing charges; (iii) a shadow wage rate for
labor at 80 per cent of the existing wages; and (iv) the exclusion of all transfer payment. Details
of the assumptions used are given in Appendix 5.

3.	

Sensitivity Analysis

106. A sensitivity analysis carried out to test the viability of the Project with various
adverse changes show that the Project is economically viable. Either a 10 per cent drop in
revenue or a 10 per cent rise in cost would not depress the EIRR below 12 per cent. A one-year
delay in benefit accrual lowers the base case EIRR by less than two percentage points. The
worst situation is assumed when a 10 per cent decline in Project revenue is accompanied by
an unanticipated cost overrun of the same magnitude. Even under such an adverse condition,
the EIRR remains at about 11 per cent, suggesting the Project is economically viable.

107. The major risks that could adversely affect implementation of the Project relate
to slower-than-anticipated adoption rate of improved farming practices arising from the
remoteness of the Project sites and less-than-full participation by the indigenous farmers in

development, institutional strengthening and support services is aimed at abating some of the
risks associated with the Project. The Project organizational structure is carefully designed to
ensure that timely staffing and logistic support is provided to the PMUs at the field level. The
provision of an extensive farmers' training program, including a special program for women, and
farming system research in all ecological zones ensure that appropriate farming practices and
production technology will be adopted by indigenous farmers in a timely manner. The
socioeconomic baseline and soil survey and a mid-term review in year three are part of an

Environmental Impact

23

An lEE concluded that the proposed Project would have positive impact in
108.
stabilizing the environment through rational land use and soil conservation measures. Based on
these positive impacts, no detailed environment impact assessment is required.

The development of tree crops and the planting of legume conservation strips will
109.
have important positive effects on the soil and minor effects on the hydrology of the area. Tree
crops may result in lower surface runoff and the tree legume strips will form wind breaks that
ameliorate the adverse effects  of the strong highland winds. The key aspects  of soil
improvement are reduced soil erosion, slumps and land slides and improved fertility and
physical status of the soil by improving the cropping systems. The planting of tree crops and
legume strips will provide ground cover to reduce surface erosion. The deeper root systems
will stabilize the soil against mass movement and bring nutrients to the surface. The legumes
will fix nitrogen and the combination of tree crops with legume strips will provide organic matter
from mulch and leaf litter. There may be some minor negative effects during land preparation
but these will be minimized by the use of manual methods in clearing and by the planting of
legume cover crops during the establishment phase.

The rotation of legumes with food and vegetable crops, and, where land pressure
110.
is less, the planting of legume fallow crops when the land is not in use, will preserve and
increase the soil fertility and thereby reduce the need for using the traditional swidden system.
Areas in the Baliem valley have been continuously under food crops and legumes for five years
without any decline in soil fertility, using conservation farming techniques. Water quality in terms
of run oft and sediment load is expected to improve under the Project. During implementation
it will be important to understand that the construction of bench terraces, so popular in Java,
where some very stable soils occur, should be actively resisted. Making bench terraces and
constructing bunds that impound water may cause iandslips in the predominantly sedimentary
soils of the Project areas.

Road rehabilitation and improvement may generate some negative impacts if it
111.
is not done with due regard to drainage aspects. Roads cut into the sides of hills without
adequate drainage may encourage excessive infiltration of water, causing the soil to become
fluid and prone to slips. Furthermore, exposure of the soil during road construction causes
erosion especially if untrained construction crews sidecast soil into drainage lines. Roads
should be adequately graded to allow run off of excess water, and banks and other exposed
surfaces should be planted with cover crops as soon as the earthworks are completed.
Exposed areas should be completely seeded with legume crops or grasses that will form an
effective cover.

Impacts on flora and fauna are not likely to be significant as the proposed
112.
development areas support a mixture of low secondary growth, temporary arable crops and
grassland as part of the shifting cultivation system. In these circumstances clearing vegetation
for cropping is not usually environmentally damaging. None of the development areas possess
their original assembly of species and in some instances very considerable reduction and
simplification has occurred because of previous farming activities. No rare or endangered
species are known to be involved. The Project plans to promote low input technology with a
minimal use of fertilizers and pesticides, and, in the Baliem valley area, small quantity of 'organic
coffee' is currently being produced for the export market. Organically grown vegetables are
being produced by indigenous farmers and sold to Free Port. The rules for organic crop
production are stringent and involve inspections and the acquisition of licenses, the use of pest-
resistant plant varieties, crop rotation and intercropping and quarantine and crop hygiene.
These procedures will be promoted under the Project so that the effect of agricultural chemicals
on insects, other wildlife and water quality will be minimal.

No serious social or cultural tensions are discernible at present, and Project
113.
activities that will lead to a higher standard of living are more likely to be positive than negative.

SocIal Dimensions

(a) Women In Development

114.
The gender dMsion of labor in indigenous Inan societies allocates distinct and
separate activities for males and females. Traditionally, males were assigned the primary tasks
of warfare, politics and ritual, and women were assigned food production and other family
subsistence activities. Besides politics and warfare, men's work also involves heavy land
clearing, the felling and barking of sago trees, hunting and fishing, making and maintaining
fences to keep out pigs, preparing raised beds for planting root crops and constructing and
repairing buildings. Women's work involves agricultural food production, harvesting crops,
marketing surplus agricultural produce, raising pigs, gathering and carrying firewood and water,
child care and other domestic chores.

Recognizing that agriculture is traditionally assigned to women in Irian society,
115.
the Project has a women-in-development program to ensure that women are not marginalized
or displaced by the Project, have access to Project inputs and receive Project benefits. The
women-in-development program has been devised to mitigate potential negative consequences
of expanding tree crops into both the male sphere of activity and into the Irianese farming
system. Experience elsewhere has shown the introduction of cash crops can and often does
increase women's workloads since they must contribute labor to cash crops in addition to their
normal tasks of food production.

The Project's emphasis on food crop production is designed to increase yields
116.
and reduce the time and energy required for food production. The Project will help introduce
simple cultivation technology, high yielding varieties and cropping systems that will significantly
increase farm yields per unit area, thereby reducing the time required for food production
activities. Extensive training on improved farm production techniques and sustainable farming
systems will be provided to women farmers. Also, women farmers will be assisted with the
supply of inputs such as improved seeds and planting materials, fruit tree seedlings, farm tools
and extension advice. The provision of village water supply systems will also contribute to
reducing women's time in fetching water from distant sources.

Women's work load could also be lightened by providing conservation strips
117.
(trees) near the villages. Firewood collection, one of the women's many routine chores, would
no longer need to be carried out over long distances. The conservation strips would also
stabilize the soils and protect the natural forests from further depletion.

Overall, the Project will seek to ensure equal participation of women in all Project
118.
activities and especially in new techniques of farm and tree crop management. A women-in-
development specialist and two community development advisors will promote and facilitate
women's involvement and participation in the overall project. Information and training in areas
such as family planning, health, nutrition, sanitation and child care will also be made available
to women. Women-in-development centers will be provided by the Project to serve as venues
for activities related to women's issues.

(b)	

Health Improvement

119. Apart from income generation, the food crop improvement program will enhance
the level of food security of participating households. Increases in food crop commodities and
livestock will expand the range of nutritious food available to the local community, leading to
an improvement in general health. Health improvement will be further augmented by the

 25

provision of spring-ted water supply systems and the construction of shallow wells in the
targeted villages. This will reduce villagers' dependence on surface water for domestic
consumption, thereby lowering their exposure to waterbome parasites and hence the incidence
of sickness and diseases related to the intake of stream and river water. The development of
shallow wells and spring-fed water supply will also eliminate the need for women and children
to ferry water from distant streams.

(c)	

AccessibIlity

120.
The rural road rehabilitation and maintenance program will not only improve
physical access to settlements and farm holdings, but, more importantly, will enlarge villagers'
accessibility to off-farm, nontarm opportunities. More accessible settlements implies that both
the marketing of farm produce and the delivery of goods and services to the villages will be
greatly facilitated, leading to a rise in farm-gate prices and a general concomitant reduction in
prices of goods imported from outside. It also means that agricultural extension services, health
care, and a host of other social services could be rendered more effectively.

121.
Access improvement would also engender a process of innovation diffusion,  an
essential element for economic growth and social progress. Many of the indigenous tribal
groups are still very much shielded from external influences. Lack of contact with the outside
world impedes technology transfer and cultural exchanges, hindering social and economic
progress. The rural infrastructure development program will expose the indigenous tribes to
activities outside their community, facilitate the flows of information and knowledge, and put
them in touch with developments external to their society.

122.
While efforts will be directed toward the development of sustainable agricultural
models in the targeted villages, the replicability of these models for comparable agro-ecologicai
zones is equally important. The present feeble transport infrastructure will not be sufficient to
effectively disseminate extension information to the remote hamlets. Thus, the rural road
development program will play a pivotal role in propagating these models to different parts of
the province. The ultimate beneficiaries will not be confined to the Project participants, but will
include the provincial population at large.
